data.title: Add legacy panel classes for theme support
data.body: All panels need to support outdated theme selectors for the time being. We were attempting to add these classes on a per-package basis but that's onerous for package authors. It will be easier to just add them in core and remove them when the time comes.

data.title: Select List styling incorrect
data.body:
The `SelectListView` just started displaying differently since Friday. It is causing wraps and clipping. I checked in Atom's Safe Mode and it is still an issue there as well. Also, I did not see any changes in the `select-list.less` file recently

**OS:** Ubuntu 14.04
**Atom:** 0.151.0-c2086ee
**UI Theme:** Atom Dark
**Syntax Theme:** Atom Monokai Dark

**UPDATE:** Seems like the `Atom Dark UI` was modified for Atom v1.0 and the selectors aren't in place, possibly?

data.title: Can't type in Atom
data.body:
With the latest release, I cannot type randomly in Atom.

However, I can press enter and move the cursor asif the program is responding. When I re-open the current file, it works.

Linux: `Linux RDI-GU 3.17.0 #1 SMP Sun Nov 23 20:55:44 PST 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux`
Distro: Ubuntu 14.04
Atom: 150

I am using a custom kernel with BFS and BFQ patched in.
However, a friend of mine is has the same problem and he is running the mainstream kernel.

data.title: Single file handling still unfriendly
data.body:
While #3355 was a significant improvement in editing individual files without opening the entire containing directory, this is only true when a project directory is already open.

On the other hand, I often create short, temporary bash scripts or quick Haskell experiments in small files in $HOME.  If I try to use Atom to edit these, then inevitably it slows to a crawl trying to deal with the many thousands of files in that directory.  If I accidentally try to pull up project symbols, or similar it will hang long enough to justify killing manually.

It would be lovely if there were a way to differentiate between opening a directory/project and opening a file.  I realize that some people consider this a feature rather than an issue, or will tell me not to put such files in $HOME, but it would be unfortunate to exclude some use cases without reason to do so.

data.title: Weird display artifact in the tab strip
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:

1. `atom --safe` 2. Open a folder 3. Open a file 4. Open Settings (doesn't look like I can reproduce this using a normal file) 5. Close one of the two files (aka not Settings) 6. Notice that there's a weird artifact left where the Settings tab was (before you closed the file) Can be fixed simply by switching or closing a tab (including Settings). Atom 0.150.0, Windows 7 x64. This has been happening since way back, but I just got around to testing it in safe mode. Two files open: ![step1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/5159245/6db8bde2-732b-11e4-8ded-844635e698d9.png) File closed: ![step2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/5159246/6f6c4bb8-732b-11e4-8ac1-aeac5fc073c3.png)

data.title: Middle mouse paste needs an extra click
data.body: The middle mouse paste that was discussed in #2244 and implemented in #4211 does not work when there is still a selection. When the cursor has been moved away from the selection pasting using the middle mouse button works. Since a middle mouse click does not set the cursor, the obvious workaround of clicking middle mouse twice on the desired location does not work.

data.title: boom!!!  Here is a hack solution to make atom start faster.
How to deal with unused config settings
data.body:
I'm changing what used to a a number of different boolean configs into an enum with the new config API. It works great, except users that have a non-default setting in their config.cson see the now unused config option in package settings. It makes the package settings confusing because options are present that no longer work. 
1. Is there any way to remove the setting beyond asking the user to manually remove it from their config?
2. If there's a reason not to remove it (messing with people's configs might be annoying), can we hide the unused setting, or give it some other visual treatment that indicates that it is not in use?

data.body:
Unable to see matching bracket indicator when cursor is below a bracket when pane is split. This can viewed in the same pane but not across panes. This would be useful to have while debugging long code blocks for bracket matching.

data.title: Preserve first line's leading whitespace on paste
data.body:
This affects the behavior of copy/paste when `Auto Indent on Paste` is turned _off_, i.e. in whitespace-sensitive languages. I think it will make things more intuitive for people. Selecting groups of lines and pasting them at column zero now works as expected.

Note that the relative indentation of the copied text is still preserved on paste, as before.

This change removes one 'Public' method - `Selection::normalizeLines`. I thought of deprecating it, but it implemented a behavior that this PR removes, and no package calls it.

Closes #4272.

data.body:
when i press alt the F in the File menu is underlined yet when i press ALT+F i get editor:move-to-end-of-word?
and when i press ALT+H to supposedly access the help menu i get editor:delete-to-beginning-of-word?
the rest of the menu keyboard shortcuts work
conflict only happens when an editor window has focus i guess
it works fine when for example all files are closed or no editor has focus
i am on windows

data.title: Wrong Reactionary dependence
data.body:
`exports/atom.coffee` requires package `reactionary` while atom only has `reactionary-atom-fork` as a dependence (https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/package.json#L53). Should require `reactionary-atom-fork` instead.

It's clear that `Reactionary` will soon be omitted from atom's module exports, but as long as fallbacks are provided, the `reactionary` package reference should be corrected. :)

data.title: ./script/grunt install --install-dir=/opt/atom  only create skeletons
data.body:
The content is left behind at /tmp/$USER/atom-build .

Its happening since 0.145 .

data.title: Doing a TextBuffer.scan with replace wipes out bookmarks?
data.body:
cc @benogle since decorations are your thing ...

Someone reported an Issue on my [tabs-to-spaces package](https://atom.io/packages/tabs-to-spaces) at lee-dohm/tabs-to-spaces#13 that bookmarks were being wiped out on every save. I've cobbled together a relatively simple repro ...

![bookmarks](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038121/5153157/0a8d764e-71ce-11e4-8e67-a99c9e91efda.gif)
## Repro Steps
1. Open up a file
2. Add a bookmark somewhere in the text
3. Open up the JavaScript console
4. Execute: `editor = atom.workspace.getActiveEditor()`
5. Execute: `buffer = editor.getBuffer()`
6. Execute: `buffer.scan(/^ /g, function(obj) { obj.replace("\t") })`

**Expected:** The bookmark remains
**Actual:** The bookmark disappears
## Versions
- **Atom:**       0.151.0-85fae83
- **Atom-Shell:** 0.19.2
- **OS:**         Mac OS X 10.10.1
- **Misc**
  - apm  0.111.0
  - npm  1.4.4
  - node 0.10.33
  - python 2.7.6
  - git 1.9.3

---

<small>This report was created in and posted from the Atom editor using the package `bug-report` version 0.5.0.</small>

data.body: Indent guides do not connect to each other; they are separated by a small but noticeable blank. It'd be better if the lines were connected as one straight line.

data.title: Cannot update or view packages in preferences window: tunneling socket errors
data.body:
I'm running OS X Mavericks with Atom 0.150.0 behind a corporate firewall. My (anonymized) `.apmrc` is as follows:

```
https-proxy = https://[user]:[pw]@[host]:[port]
http-proxy = http://[user]:[pw]@[host]:[port]
proxy = http://[user]:[pw]@[host]:[port]
strict-ssl = false
```

Fetching outdated packages and themes fails with this error message:

```
Request for package information failed: tunneling socket could not be established, cause=140735230071568:error:140770FC:SSL routines:SSL23_GET_SERVER_HELLO:unknown protocol:../deps/openssl/openssl/ssl/s23_clnt.c:795:
```

Fetching featured packages fails with this error message:

```
tunneling socket could not be established, cause=140735230071568:error:140770FC:SSL routines:SSL23_GET_SERVER_HELLO:unknown protocol:../deps/openssl/openssl/ssl/s23_clnt.c:795:
```

Googling and further searching doesn't seem to bring up anything immediately relevant and helpful. I'd really like to use Atom as my primary text editor, but I have no idea how to get past these issues. Thank you in advance for your time and help.

data.title: Package settings getting reset
data.body:
I am not sure if this is an Atom issue or a problem with the package `linter` since it is the only one I change settings on. I thought I would check here first. The issue I am having is, I change the setting and after a restart the setting is back to the default. As you can imagine, this is very annoying to have to reset every time.

**System Information**
- **OS:** Ubuntu 14.04
- **Atom Version:** [0.151.0-f79b780](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/f79b78054cc04be6e8ca6c79189c46ad22f31969)
- **Linter:** [AtomLinter/Linter](https://github.com/AtomLinter/Linter) v0.7.3

**Steps to Reproduce**
1. Open Atom
2. Open Settings (`ctrl-,`)
3. Navigate to `linter` package settings
4. Un-check "Show Status Bar When Cursor Is In Error Range
5. Close Atom
6. Repeat Steps 1-3

If this is a problem with the package, I will gladly move it to the correct repository.
